explanation:
OS_object_token_t: needed to know the layout and mutability of token->obj_idx and any other fields accessed; determining whether members are modified (so pointer must be non-const) or only read (could be const) requires the type.

OS_impl_console_internal_record_t: required to see the fields (e.g., data_sem) that are written (sem_init/sem_destroy) so we can decide whether the pointer local should be a pointer-to-const or a mutable pointer.

OS_console_internal_record_t: required to inspect fields (e.g., IsAsync) to see whether console is only read (and so could be const-qualified) or written to by this function.

OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t: required to know the exact types and constness of members id and opaque_arg (union/struct) because the code assigns to id and passes opaque_arg; this affects whether local_arg or its members should be const-qualified.

OS_ObjectIdFromToken: prototype/return type is needed to determine the type assigned to local_arg.id and whether the returned value or its use implies any const requirements.

OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: macro definition (or inline function) is needed to determine what type and const-qualification it yields for local and console (e.g., whether it returns a pointer to mutable or const records).

OS_console_table and OS_impl_console_table: the actual table declarations (element types/constness) may influence what pointer type OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET returns; needed to decide if the result should be pointer-to-const.

OS_Posix_InternalTaskCreate_Impl: prototype is required to know the expected type/constness of the task-argument parameter (opaque arg) so we can determine whether passing local_arg.opaque_arg violates const rules.

OS_ConsoleTask_Entry: the task entry function signature is needed to know the type/constness of the argument that the new task expects (void * vs const void *), which affects whether opaque_arg should be const.

sem_init and sem_destroy: prototypes indicate that data_sem is modified via a non-const sem_t*, so these functions are evidence that local (owner of data_sem) cannot be const; include these to confirm mutability.

sem_t: the type of data_sem member is needed to confirm that sem_init/sem_destroy operate on a mutable semaphore object and therefore local must be mutable rather than const.
